awd_titl_txt: Gateways-ND: Advancing Learner-Focused Instruction to Catalyze Student Success
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, "Gateways-ND: Advancing Learner-Focused Instruction to Catalyze Student Success," will improve student learning by implementing an innovative and comprehensive model for the professional development of faculty and instructional staff at the college level.  Project goals are to increase instructor use of evidence-based active-learning strategies and analytics that increase teaching effectiveness, to enhance student-learning outcomes, to increase retention in STEM fields, and to improve student attitudes toward STEM learning. The project will significantly improve the understanding and effectiveness of 150 instructional staff at North Dakota State University (NDSU) who, during the project period alone, will support over 12,500 first-year students in first-year STEM courses. Changing the nature of teaching and learning at NDSU will have a broad impact on the state and beyond by preparing future graduates with the STEM knowledge and abilities needed to meet state employment needs and able to grapple effectively with important economic and social issues that have an impact on North Dakota and the nation, such as oil and gas exploration, health care, and agriculture.

Gateways-ND will significantly improve the culture of STEM Education at North Dakota State University (NDSU), strengthen faculty teaching skills, and increase student learning outcomes and retention by providing professional development workshops, faculty learning communities, resources, and support for the faculty who teach gateway STEM courses. Faculty will learn to use proven active, collaborative, learner-focused pedagogy, and to utilize robust data analytics about student learning to guide their teaching. Faculty members will participate in a two-year professional development (PD) series, including a one-week intensive teaching workshop, monthly Faculty Learning Community (FLC) meetings, training in use of data analytics, mid-year follow-up, and a second year of advanced professional development. Gateways-ND research activities will examine relationships between high-impact teaching practices and improved student outcomes (i.e., learning outcomes, retention in STEM majors, and attitudes toward STEM learning). Project-based research will also examine faculty beliefs regarding teaching strategies before and after participation in professional development. Institutional cultural transformation will impact over 12,500 incoming students enrolling in gateway courses during the 5-year grant period.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report – NSF Award # 1525056

Project Title: Gateways-ND: Advancing Learner-Focused Instruction to Catalyze Student Success

Recipient Organization: North Dakota State University

Project/Grant Period: 09/01/2015 – 8/31/2021

PI: James Nyachwaya.

Gateways-ND was a full design and development project that provided tools, resources, and methods (TRMs) documented to improve student learning outcomes to faculty members who taught lower level undergraduate (gateway) STEM courses at North Dakota State University (NDSU). Gateways-ND also sought to examine the relationship between use of high-impact teaching practices and improved student outcomes (i.e., learning outcomes, retention in STEM majors, and attitudes toward STEM learning). Faculty members participated in a two-year professional development (PD) series that included a one-week intensive workshop with experts in innovative teaching practices; monthly Faculty Learning Community (FLC) meetings; provision of and assistance with early warning system tools, including predictive analytics; mid-year follow-up; and a second year of advanced development, with disciplinary FLCs.  

Gateways-ND sought to influence beliefs about teaching and learning held by both faculty and students in gateway courses undergoing instructional improvement, all with the understanding that beliefs shape behaviors. Project-based research questions included examining beliefs held by faculty members regarding teaching strategies (prior to and following participation in PD) and measuring the success of students enrolled in courses in which learner-focused practices are newly employed. Because institutional social norms and individual behavior can be hard to change with short-term or one-shot Professional Development, Gateways-ND sought to examine the effects of long-term (i.e., two-year) continuous engagement with STEM pedagogical best practices. Furthermore, to formulate methods for improving the quantity and quality of student-teacher interactions outside the classroom, we needed, in part, to understand student beliefs about such interactions.

The cohort model developed by Gateways-ND provided a structured, collaborative environment most suited to first-time or early-career learners of high-impact instructional methods. NDSU was in an opportune position to implement this large-scale PD program to stimulate and be stimulated by concurrent positive institutional cultural change, including general education redesign, Teaching Assistant (TA) training, construction of a STEM classroom building with flexible-use classroom space, and investment in the redesign of gateway courses. As such, the emphasis not only on learner-focused teaching strategies, but also best practices for implementation and campus-wide continuing support for instructors set the stage for NDSU to study and model institutional best practices for realigning campus-wide teaching and learning practices.

Gateways-ND impacted the culture of STEM Education at NDSU (and beyond) by:

 1) providing professional development, which focused on the use of active and collaborative learning strategies, for 170 faculty and staff;

2) cultivating faculty learning communities, thereby creating a long-term, supportive and supported campus-wide community of engaged faculty;

3) generating cohorts of faculty practicing learner-focused teaching that will define NDSU’s teaching culture; and

4) becoming a model institutional STEM education training program for sharing best practices of institutional development at a national level. We have disseminated products of our work through journal publications and presentations at national and international conferences.

Cultural transformation at the institutional level has, and will continue to impact the educational experiences of over 75% of NDSU’s incoming first-year students who will enroll in a STEM gateway course in their first year. Early experiences with active and collaborative classroom learning sets the tone for students’ expectations of self and of the institution throughout their educational career. Over the course of the grant, Gateways-ND trained faculty taught over 21,000 unique students. Among other impacts, Gateways-ND led to more student success as evidenced by low failure rates in courses, higher average scores in courses and higher retention rates in STEM disciplines.

NDSU’s well-documented contributions to the North Dakota economy are dependent upon the ability of its graduates to draw upon higher-order, transferable skills. The rapid growth of North Dakota’s economy calls for skilled health-care workers to attend to the needs of a growing population; continued success in fields such as oil production calls for STEM graduates to collaboratively balance the positive and negative impacts of such oil production methods as fracking and land use; and North Dakota’s historically and currently successful agricultural economy requires sustained high-quality educational opportunities at the land-grant institution (i.e., NDSU). Implementation of learner-focused practices in gateway courses has, and will continue to help retain greater numbers of students in STEM fields by providing them with learning experiences and student-faculty interactions that bolster self-efficacy and motivation for learning in STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2021
Modified by: James Nyachwaya
